metadata.case_name: Appellant Firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appellants, a firm carrying on business in cloth at Secunderabad, applied on June 30, 1955, for registration under s. 26-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, for the assessment year 1956-57.

The application recited the following partners with shares in profits and losses: 1. Messrs Kylasa Sarabhiah, a firm (Yarn Shop) consisting of partners Kylasa Veeresalingam, Kylasa Nagendrarao, Kylasa Madhusudhanarao (0-6-9), Mahendrakar Narayanarao (0-3-3), Nune Vittayya (0-2-6), Pottupalli Chandrayya (0-2-6), Gande Ramayya (0-1-0).

Four minors - K. Rajeshwarrao, K. Haranath Babu, K. Ramesh Babu and Shivakumar - admitted to the benefits of the partnership with equal shares in the profits falling to the share of the Yarn Shop; losses shared equally only by major partners K. Veeresalingam, Nagendrarao and K. Madhusudhanarao.
Yarn Shop constituted under instrument dated May 12, 1955, amending deed dated February 20, 1952.
Income-tax Officer rejected the application for registration.
Rejection confirmed in appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed rejection, holding that benefits to minors not specified, particulars of profit/loss distribution not given, and Yarn Shop introduced as a partner.

Andhra Pradesh High Court answered negatively the question referred under s. 66(1): 'Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the assessee is entitled to registration under s. 26-A of the Income-tax Act?' dated August 18, 1960.
Application signed by major partners, accompanied by original instrument, certificate of prior year profits given.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the assessee is entitled to registration under s. 26-A of the Income-tax Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Deed of partnership specifies individual shares of partners, including division among Yarn Shop members and minors' benefits; application conforms to rules; signed by majors; Yarn Shop members are individual partners.
Defect in Yarn Shop's own deed does not affect appellant firm's registration.

respondent_arguments.text: Benefits to minors admitted not specified; no particulars of profit/loss distribution; Yarn Shop introduced as partner; no profit sharing ratio in Yarn Shop deed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 26-A Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; Dulichand Laxminarayan v. CIT

court_reasoning.text: Requirements of s. 26-A and rules must be strictly complied with for registration benefit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Registration if firm lawfully constituted under instrument specifying individual shares and ITO satisfied of genuine firm.

court_reasoning.text: Deed must be reasonably construed; firm not a legal person, agreement by firm name makes partners individual partners.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Collective share of Yarn Shop specified as 0-6-9, with internal division recited in preamble for profits/losses and minors.

court_reasoning.text: Substance not overshadowed by collective description; agreement between seven individuals (three majors and four others of Yarn Shop); all signed as majors.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Shares clearly defined though not in precise fractions; 'specify' means mentioning/describing in detail.

court_reasoning.text: Dulichand case distinguished: here shares specified, all relevant members signed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Yarn Shop deed defect irrelevant to appellant firm's registration.

holdings.text: Assessee entitled to registration under s. 26-A; High Court answer discharged, affirmative answer recorded.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dulichand Laxminarayan v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Nagpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Held partnership between individual, HUF, firms could not be registered as firm cannot be partner and not all signed; distinguished here as shares specified and signed properly.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs registration of firms; requires instrument specifying individual shares; rules for application.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribe form, signing by partners (not minors), original deed, satisfaction for certificate, renewal.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines partnership as relation between persons agreeing to share profits; firm not a person.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave allowed; High Court's negative answer to reference discharged; affirmative answer recorded that assessee entitled to registration under s. 26-A.

key_quotes.text: the substance of the agreement cannot be permitted to be overshadowed merely by the use of the collective description of some of the persons who agreed to be partners.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes looking at true partners despite firm name usage.

key_quotes.text: The word 'specify' is used in s. 26-A and Rule 2 as meaning, mentioning, describing or defining in detail it does not mean expressly setting out in fractional or other shares.
key_quotes.speaker: court
